data.text:
Pioneers of Science by Robert Weber, Adam Hilger, pp 310, Pounds sterling

12.95

OPEN this book, and you’ll find two-page biographies of the 130 Nobel

laureates in physics from the first, Wilhelm Konrad Rontgen in 1901, through

to Karl Muller and Georg Bednorz, the prizewinners in 1987. My first reaction

to Pioneers of Science was scepticism. By all rational standards, Albert

Einstein, winner in 1921, should not be given the same amount of space as

Charles-Edouard Guillaume, the winner the previous year. Moreover, what

can possibly be said about Einstein, Paul Dirac, Lev Landau or Richard Feynman

that has not been said in greater detail elsewhere? The answer is, nothing;

and one should not look for anything new about such luminaries. The book’s

interest – and it is curiously interesting – comes from the relative unknowns.

As the author, Robert Weber, points out in the preface, the Nobel prize

is awarded not for a lifetime’s contribution but for a particular achievement.

Thus we find in the list a number of individuals who are hardly household

names. Many of us will have difficulty recalling the scientific contributions

made by Guillaume (1920), Gabriel Lippmann (1908), or Nils Gustaf Dalen

(1912). And yet, as the brief biographies make clear, these were outstanding

individuals. Even the least-known of the Nobel laureates was an exceptional

person.

The list also contains some surprising omissions, of scientists of the

first magnitude, such as Sommerfeld, Edwin Hubble, Arthur Eddington, and

John Wheeler, which suggest that the Nobel committee is far from infallible.

Other absences, such as Henry Moseley, are explained by his early death.

As Weber points out in his introduction, the Nobel prize is awarded only

to the living.

Pioneers of Science is a book to dip into, rather than to read through

steadily. But it has a strange fascination, and one dips into it again and

again.

(For the curious: Lippmann won the prize for his method of colour photography;

Dalen, for the invention of automatic regulators used on beacons and light

buoys; Guillaume, for the discovery of low-expansion nickel alloys.)
